author: S Poorvaja
text:
A few days after a report of tourists taking selfies with a dolphin that had been washed ashore on a beach in Santa Teresita in Argentina, timely action by the Forest Department, fishermen and volunteers ensured that a dolphin here did not face a similar situation on Thursday.

Clement Edison, a forester, said they were alerted by fishermen from Urur Kuppam in Besant Nagar about a spinner dolphin near the shore.

“We found that the dolphin had a few superficial injuries on its hind limbs and nose and was struggling to swim back,” he said.

Spinner dolphins are found along the coast in Chennai and an adult spinner dolphin, such as the one found on Thursday, is usually around four feet long and two feet wide. Shravan Krishnan, an animal rescue volunteer who was also at the spot, said the rough waves deterred the injured dolphin from getting back into the sea.

“Along with fishermen and Forest Department officials there, we decided to take the dolphin back to the sea, at least by 3 km, with a fishing boat,” he said.

After ointments were applied to its wounds, the dolphin was tied to the boat and taken to the sea.

“We could not risk its being out of water even for a little while so had to transport it that way,” Mr. Krishnan said.

Karunakaran, a fisherman and supervisor of an olive ridley hatchery on the beach, said the volunteers waited mid-sea for about an hour to ensure that the dolphin was alright and did not get washed ashore again.

title: Injured dolphin towed, released into sea
